levels.title: Navigate Home
levels.story: You're in /var/log. You need to get back home. Use 'pwd' to see where you are, then navigate to your home directory.
levels.hint: Use 'cd' (change directory) to navigate. You can use ~ as shortcut for home.

levels.title: Hidden Files Revealed
levels.story: You're in /home/user. Your boss hid the .SAASApp directory (it starts with a dot so it's hidden). Find it using ls with the right flag.
levels.objective: List all files including hidden ones
levels.response: ✓ Found it! .SAASApp is revealed (along with .bashrc, .profile, .cache, etc.)
levels.hint: The flag -a shows ALL files (including hidden ones that start with .)

levels.title: Enter the Hidden Directory
levels.story: Now that you see .SAASApp, navigate into it. You'll find your project there.
levels.response: ✓ You're now inside .SAASApp. Time to get to work!
levels.hint: You can use relative path (cd .SAASApp) or absolute path (cd /home/user/.SAASApp)

levels.title: What's in This Directory?
levels.story: You're in .SAASApp. List the files to see what's here. Your project has package.json, src folder, and a README.
levels.hint: Use ls -l to see detailed info: permissions, size, date modified, etc.

levels.title: Go Back One Directory
levels.story: You went too deep into a nested folder. Get back to parent directory using 'cd ..'
levels.response: ✓ You're back in /home/user/.SAASApp. Parent directory reached!
levels.hint: cd .. = go up one level. cd ../.. = go up two levels. cd - = go back to previous directory

levels.title: Create a New Folder
levels.story: You need to create a new folder called 'languageapp' for your next project.
levels.objective: Create a new directory called languageapp
levels.hint: mkdir = make directory. Use mkdir -p to create nested folders automatically.

levels.title: Install Dependencies
levels.story: You're in a new project folder that has package.json. Install the dependencies using npm.
levels.hint: npm install = read package.json and download all dependencies. npm i is shorthand.

levels.title: Check Git Status
levels.story: You've made changes to your project. Check git status to see what's changed.
levels.hint: git status = see what files have changed, what's staged, what's untracked

levels.title: Set Git Remote
levels.story: Time to push to GitHub! First, set your remote origin to your GitHub repo. Use git remote add origin [URL]
levels.objective: Add remote origin for GitHub push
levels.hint: git remote add origin [URL] = connect to GitHub. Check your GitHub repo for the exact URL.

levels.title: Push to GitHub
levels.story: Your changes are committed. Now push them to GitHub using git push. This is the final step to ship!
levels.response: ✓ Code pushed to GitHub successfully! Your project is now live!
levels.hint: git push = send commits to GitHub. -u flag sets upstream. After first push, just 'git push' works.
levels.lesson: git push = ship your code to the world

commandHelp.ls:
ls - list directory contents

SYNOPSIS
  ls [OPTION]... [FILE]...

DESCRIPTION
  List information about the FILEs (the current directory by default).

OPTIONS
  -a, --all              Do not ignore hidden files (those starting with .)
  -A, --almost-all       Like -a, but do not list implied . and ..
  -l                     Use a long listing format
  -h, --human-readable   Print human readable file sizes (1K 2M 1G)
  -S                     Sort by file size, largest first
  -t                     Sort by time modified, most recently modified first
  -r, --reverse          Reverse order while sorting
  -R, --recursive        List subdirectories recursively
  -d, --directory        List directory entries instead of contents
  --group-directories-first  Group directories first, before files
  -v, --version          Output version information and exit
  --help                 Display this help and exit

EXAMPLES
  ls                    List files in current directory
  ls -a                 List all files including hidden
  ls -la                List all files in long format
  ls -lah               List all files in long format with human-readable sizes
  ls -lS                List files sorted by size
  ls -lt                List files sorted by modification time
  ls -R                 List subdirectories recursively
